org.descripter.js.api.core

Class CArray

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.descripter.js.api.Context<Key,java.lang.Object,W>
      • org.descripter.js.api.Objective<CObject>
        • org.descripter.js.api.core.CObject
          • org.descripter.js.api.core.CArray

  • public class CArray
extends CObject

    Emulates JavaScript Array objects.

    Since:
    Descripter 1.0
    Author:
    J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.descripter.org

      • concat

        public final CArray concat(CArray args)

        Creates and returns a new array object that is the result of concatenating the arguments to the current array instance. This invocation does not modify the current array.

        Parameters:
        args - An array of values to be concatenated with the current array.
        Returns:
        A new array object, which is formed by concatenating the specified arguments to the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0

      • join

        public final java.lang.String join()

        Converts each element of the current array instance to a string and then concatenates those strings, inserting a comma between the elements and returns the resulting string.

        Returns:
        The string that results from converting each element of the current array to a string and then concatenating them together with a comma between elements.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        join(String)

      • join

        public final java.lang.String join(java.lang.String separator)

        Converts each element of the current array instance to a string and then concatenates those strings, inserting the separator string specified by separator between the elements and returns the resulting string.

        Parameters:
        separator - An optional string used to separate one element of the current array from the next in the returned string. If this argument is omitted, undefined or null, a comma is used.
        Returns:
        The string that results from converting each element of the current array to a string and then concatenating them together, with the separator string between elements.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        join()

      • pop

        public final java.lang.Object pop()

        Deletes the last element of the current array instance, decrements the length of the current array, and returns the value of the deleted element. If the current array is already empty, this invocation does not change the array and returns the undefined null value.

        Returns:
        The last element of the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0

      • push

        public final int push(CArray args)

        Appends the arguments to the end of the current array instance by modifying the array directly rather than creating a new one.

        Parameters:
        args - An array of values to be appended to the end of the current array.
        Returns:
        The new length of the array, after the specified value are appended to it.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0

      • reverse

        public final CArray reverse()

        Reverses the order of the elements of the current array instance by rearranging them in place without creating a new array. If there are multiple references to the array, the new order of the array elements is visible through all references after this invocation.

        Returns:
        The reversed array
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0

      • shift

        public final java.lang.Object shift()

        Removes and returns the first element of the current array instance, shifting all subsequent elements down one place to occupy the newly vacant space at the start of the array. If the current array is empty, this invocation does nothing and returns the undefined value null. Note that this invocation does not create a new array; instead, it modifies the current array directly.

        Returns:
        The former first element of the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        pop()

      • slice

        public final CArray slice(CArray args)

        Returns a slice, or sub-array, of the current array instance without modifying it. The returned array contains the element positioned by the first value of the argument list and all subsequent elements up to, but not including, the element positioned by the second value of the argument list. If the second value is not specified or undefined, the returned array contains all elements from the position specified by the first value to the end of the current array.

        Parameters:
        args - A list of the argument values. The first value specifies the array index at which the slice is to begin. If this value is negative, it specifies a position measured from the end of the current array. That is, -1 indicates the last element, -2 indicates the next from the last element, and so on. The second value specifies the array index immediately after the end of the slice. If it is undefined or not specified, the slice includes all array elements from the position specified by the first value to the end of the array. If the second value is negative, it specifies the array element measured from the end of the array.
        Returns:
        A new array that contains the elements of current array instance from the element positioned by the first value of args, up to, but not including, the element positioned by the second value of args.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        slice(int), slice(int, int), splice(CArray), splice(int), splice(int, int), splice(int, int, CArray)

      • slice

        public final CArray slice(int start)

        Returns a slice, or sub-array, of the current array instance without modifying it. The returned array contains the element positioned by start and all subsequent elements up to the end of the current array.

        Parameters:
        start - The array index at which the slice is to begin. If negative, this argument specifies a position measured from the end of the current array. That is, -1 indicates the last element, -2 indicates the next from the last element, and so on.
        Returns:
        A new array that contains the elements of current array instance from the element positioned by start, up to the end of the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        slice(CArray), slice(int, int), splice(CArray), splice(int), splice(int, int), splice(int, int, CArray)

      • slice

        public final CArray slice(int start,
           int end)

        Returns a slice, or sub-array, of the current array instance without modifying it. The returned array contains the element positioned by start and all subsequent elements up to, but not including, the element positioned by end. If end is an undefined value, the returned array contains all elements from the start to the end of the current array.

        Parameters:
        start - The array index at which the slice is to begin. If negative, this argument specifies a position measured from the end of the current array. That is, -1 indicates the last element, -2 indicates the next from the last element, and so on.
        end - The array index immediately after the end of the slice. If undefined, the slice includes all array elements from the start to the end of the array. If this argument is negative, it specifies an array element measured from the end of the array.
        Returns:
        A new array that contains the elements of current array instance from the element positioned by start, up to, but not including, the element positioned by end.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        slice(CArray), slice(int), splice(CArray), splice(int), splice(int, int), splice(int, int, CArray)

      • sort

        public final CArray sort()

        Sorts the elements of the current array instance in place by arranging them in alphabetical order (more precisely, the order determined by the character encoding). To do this, elements are first converted to strings, if necessary, so that they can be compared. Note that the array is sorted in place, and no copy is made. And undefined elements are always sorted to the end of the array.

        Returns:
        A reference to the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        sort(Function)

      • sort

        public final CArray sort(Function<?> orderer)

        Sorts the elements of the current array instance with the custom ordering function orderer. Note that the array is sorted in place, and no copy is made. And undefined elements are always sorted to the end of the array because undefined values are never passed to the ordering function you supply.

        Parameters:
        orderer - A comparison function that compares two values and returns a number indicating their relative order. This function should take two arguments, a and b for instance, and should return one of the following:
        • A value less than zero, if, according to your sort criteria, a is less than b and should appear before b in the sorted array.
        • Zero, if a and b are equivalent for the purposes of this sort.
        • A value greater than zero, if a is greater than b for the purposes of the sort.
        Returns:
        A reference to the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        sort()

      • splice

        public final CArray splice(CArray args)

        Deletes elements, numbered by the second value of args, starting with and including the element positioned by the first value of args, and replaces them with the values listed by args from the third value. Array elements that appear after the insertion or deletion are moved as necessary so that they remain contiguous with the rest of the array.

        Note that, this invocation modifies the current array directly.

        Parameters:
        args - A list of the argument values. The first value specifies the array index at which the deletion and insertion is to begin. The second value specifies the number of elements, starting with and including the element positioned by the first value, to be deleted from the current array. If the second value is undefined, this invocation deletes all elements from the position specified by the first value to the end of the array. The rest of the list provides the values to be inserted into the current array, beginning at the position specified by the first value.
        Returns:
        An array containing the elements, if any, deleted from the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        slice(CArray), slice(int), slice(int, int), splice(int), splice(int, int), splice(int, int, CArray)

      • splice

        public final CArray splice(int start)

        Deletes zero or more array elements starting with and including the element positioned by start.

        Note that, this invocation modifies the current array directly.

        Parameters:
        start - The array index at which the insertion and/or deletion is to begin.
        Returns:
        An array containing the elements, if any, deleted from the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        slice(CArray), slice(int), slice(int, int), splice(CArray), splice(int, int), splice(int, int, CArray)

      • splice

        public final CArray splice(int start,
            int deleteCount)

        Deletes deleteCount elements of the current array instance starting with and including the element positioned by start. Array elements that appear after deletion are moved as necessary so that they remain contiguous with the rest of the array.

        Note that, this invocation modifies the current array directly.

        Parameters:
        start - The array index at which the deletion is to begin.
        deleteCount - The number of elements, starting with and including the element positioned by start, to be deleted from the current array. If this argument is undefined, this invocation deletes all elements from start to the end of the array.
        Returns:
        An array containing the elements, if any, deleted from the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        slice(CArray), slice(int), slice(int, int), splice(CArray), splice(int), splice(int, int, CArray)

      • splice

        public final CArray splice(int start,
            int deleteCount,
            CArray values)

        Deletes deleteCount elements starting with and including the element positioned by start and replaces them with the argument values. Array elements that appear after the insertion or deletion are moved as necessary so that they remain contiguous with the rest of the array.

        Note that, this invocation modifies the current array directly.

        Parameters:
        start - The array index at which the deletion and insertion is to begin.
        deleteCount - The number of elements, starting with and including the element positioned by start, to be deleted from the current array. If this argument is undefined, this invocation deletes all elements from start to the end of the array.
        values - The array of values to be inserted into the current array, beginning at the index specified by start.
        Returns:
        An array containing the elements, if any, deleted from the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        slice(CArray), slice(int), slice(int, int), splice(CArray), splice(int), splice(int, int)

      • unshift

        public final int unshift(CArray values)

        Inserts the arguments at the beginning of the current array instance, shifting the existing elements to higher indexes to make room. The first argument becomes the new element 0 of the array. Note that this invocation does not create a new array; it modifies the current array directly.

        Parameters:
        values - An array of values that are inserted at the start of the current array.
        Returns:
        The new length of the current array.
        Since:
        Descripter 1.0
        See Also:
        shift()
